Ar. Th. 278; ὕστερος ἐλθεῖν τοῦ σ. Id. V. 690: generally, signal, σ. ὑποδηλῶσαί τινι ὅτι . . Id. Th. 1011; τὰ σ. αὐτοῖς ἤρθη Th. 4.42; τὸ σ. τοῦ πυρός, ὡς εἴρητο, ἀνέσχον ib. 111; signal to commence work, [ ἡ] τοῦ σημείου ἄρσις Ath.Mitt. 35.403 (Pergam.); σημείῳ ἀβαστάκτῳ, σημείοις ἀβαστάκτοις with unremoved signal ( s), of gymnasia, i.e. never closed, IGRom. 4.446 (ibid.), Abh.Berl.Akad. 1932(5).44 (ibid., ii A.D.).
standard or flag, on the admiralʼs ship, Hdt. 8.92; on the generalʼs tent, X. Cyr. 8.5.13; ἔξω τῶν σ. out of the lines, ib. 8.3.19.

children.label: b
children.definition: body of troops under one standard or flag, PAmh. 2.39.2 (ii B.C.); cf. σημεία I.2.
mark, boundary, limit, ἔξω τῶν σ. τοῦ ὑμετέρου ἐμπορίου out of the limits of your commercial port, D. 35.28; of milestones, Plu. CG 7, Hdn. 2.13.9.
device upon a shield, Hdt. 1.171, E. Ph. 1114; upon ships, figure-head, Ar. Ra. 933, Th. 6.31, E. IA 255 (lyr.).

signet on ring, etc., Ar. Eq. 952, V. 585, Pl. Tht. 191d, al., X. HG 5.1.30, D. 42.2, PRev.Laws 26.5 (iii B.C.); figure, image, Διὸς κτησίου Anticl. 13; badge, τρίαιναν σ. θεοῦ A. Supp. 218: pl., written characters, γράψαι σημήϊα . . φωνῆς IG 14.1549 ( Rome).

children.label: b
children.definition: Dor.) σαμεῖα, stripes, ib. 5(1).1390.16 ( Andania, i B.C.); clavi · σημεῖα, Gloss.
watchword, war-cry, Plb. 5.69.8; ἀπὸ σ. ἑνὸς ἐπιστρέφειν τὰς ναῦς Th. 2.90, cf. X. HG 6.2.28.

data.quote: ἀπὸ σ. ἑνὸς ἐπιστρέφειν τὰς ναῦς

children.definition: birthmark or distinguishing feature, Wilcken Chr. 76.14 (ii A.D.), Sammelb. 15.27 (ii A.D.), etc.

children.label: II
children.definition: sign, token, indication of anything that is or is to be, S. OT 1059, E. Ph. 1332; σ. φαίνεις ἐσθλὸς . . γεγώς S. El. 24, cf. OT 710; τέχνης σ. τῆς ἐμῆς Id. Ant. 998; so later τὰ σ. τῶν καιρῶν Ev.Matt. 16.3, etc.

sign or proof, Ar. Nu. 369, Th. 1.6, 10, And. 2.25, etc.; τούτων ὑμῖν σημεῖα δείξω Aeschin. 2.103, cf. 3.46; τάδε τὰ σ. ὡς . . X. Ages. 1.5; σ. εἰ . . Pl. Grg. 520e; ὅτι ἀγαθὸς ἦν . ., τοῦτο μέγιστον σ. Id. Min. 321b; τὸ μὴ ἐκδυθῆναι οὐδὲν σ. ἐστι is no proof to the contrary, Antipho 2.2.5; also, instance, example, Hp. VM 20; σημεῖον δέ· to introduce an argument, D. 21.149, Isoc. 4.86,107, etc.
Arist., a sign used as a probable argument in proof of a conclusion, opp. τεκμήριον (a demonstrative or certain proof), APr. 70a11, SE 167b9, Rh. 1357a33.

children.label: b
children.definition: sign as observable basis of inference to the unobserved or unobservable, Epicur. Ep. 2p.43U., Phld. Sign. 27, al., S.E. M. 8.142, al.; περὶ σημείων (dub. sens.), title of work by Zeno, Stoic. 1.14.

children.label: b
children.definition: = Lat. lenticula, a kind of skin-eruption, Cels. 6.5.1.
shorthand symbols, Plu. Cat.Mi. 23, Gal. Libr.Propr. 1, POxy. 724.3 (ii A.D.), Lib. Or. 42.25.
critical mark, Heph. Poëm. p.73C., D.L. 3.65.

children.label: III
children.definition: mathematical point, Arist. APo. 76b5, Ph. 240b3, Euc. Def. 1, al.; also σ. (with or without χρόνου) point of time, instant, Arist. Cael. 283a11, Ph. 262b2sq.
unit of time, Aristid.Quint. 1.14, Longin. Proll. Heph. 5.
one who observes omens, diviner, Al. 1 Ki. 28.3,9.
divine, Sm. De. 18.10.

standard-bearer, Sammelb. 599.7, al. ( Ptolemaic), D.H. 8.65, Plu. Brut. 43:—also σημεαφόρος BGU 600.10, 12 (ii/iii A.D.), PFlor. 278 iii 30 (iii A.D.), IGRom. 3.57 ( Prusias), CIG 4957e ( Egypt); σημηαφόρος Sammelb. 979.7 ( Alexandria, i A.D.), CIL 3.6026 ( Syene), Stud.Pal. 22.92 (iii A.D.); σημιαφόρος Supp.Epigr. 6.535 ( Isauria), Judeich Altertümer von Hierapolis No.153; σημιαφώρος PHamb. 39 No. 16; σιμιαφόρος ib. No. 45 (ii A.D.); σημαιαφόρος (with v.l. σημαιοφόρος) Plb. 6.24.6, J. BJ 6.1.7; σημαιοφόρος also in Plu. Galb. 22.

children.label: II
children.definition: σημιαφόρος, Jahresh. 13.201 ( Alabanda, ii A.D.).

children.label: III
children.definition: signaller, Ascl. Tact. 2.9, 6.3.

definition: σημειόω ( Dor. σᾱμ- IG 5(1).1390.71 ( Andania, i B.C.)), = σημαίνω,

children.definition: mark (by milestones), Plb. 3.39.8 ( Pass.), cf. 1.47.1; seal, ἐπιστολὰς -ωμένας σφραγῖδι D.H. 4.57:— Pass., to be marked or stamped, IG l.c.
give a signal, impers. in Pass., ὅταν σημειωθῇ Aen. Tact. 22.23 (cod. M).

children.label: II
children.definition: Med., mark for oneself, note down, ὅτι . . Thphr. CP 1.21.7; τόπον Plb. 21.28.9: abs., Δυμᾶς σεσημείωμαι ( signed) Δυμᾶς, Ostr.Bodl. iii 280 (i A.D.), cf. ii 25 (i A.D.), etc.; take notice of, pay honour to . . , ὅπως ὁ δῆμος φαίνηται τοὺς καλοὺς κἀγαθοὺς τῶν ἀνδρῶν σημειούμενος Inscr.Perg. 252.28.

data.quote: ὅπως ὁ δῆμος φαίνηται τοὺς καλοὺς κἀγαθοὺς τῶν ἀνδρῶν σημειούμενος

children.definition: interpret anything as a sign or portent, Plb. 5.78.2, Str. 9.2.11; infer as from a sign, ὁ ἐκ τῆς ἐναργείας -ούμενος περὶ τῶν ἀδήλων Phld. Sign. 15, cf. Epicur. Ep. 2p.47U., S.E. M. 8.271:—Medic., diagnose, Antyll. ap. Orib. 45.2.1, Gal. 18(2).851; later, examine, σημειωσόμεθα κοπαρίῳ Paul.Aeg. 6.77; οἱ τοῦ -ουμένου δάκτυλοι ib. 96.

data.quote: ὁ ἐκ τῆς ἐναργείας -ούμενος περὶ τῶν ἀδήλων

children.definition: σημείωσαι,= nota bene, Hdn.Gr. 1.87, al., freq. in Sch.:—in Pass., σημειοῦται δὲ ὅτι . . Sch. Il. Oxy. 1086i17; τὰ σεσημειωμένα noted as exceptions, A.D. Pron. 115.11, Choerob. in Theod. 1.406 H.: fut. σεσημειώσεται A.D. Adv. 166.14.
remarkable, conspicuous, Str. 8.1.3 ( Sup.); of language, peculiar, singular, ὀνόματα D.H. Isoc. 2.

children.label: II
children.definition: significant of something to come, ἅλῳ Arist. Mete. 373a30, cf. Thphr. Vent. 35; τὰ ἐνύπνια ἔχει τι σ. Arist. Div.Somn. 462b15, cf. Phld. Sign. 19, Plu. Aet.Gr. 2.286b. Adv. -δῶς remarkably, Str. 16.2.28.
records, Vit. Philonid. p.11 C.
indication, notice, Plu. Sollert. 2.961c.

children.label: II
children.definition: inference from a sign, Phld. Sign. 2, al.; ὁ καθʼ ὁμοιότητα τρόπος τῆς σ. ib. 1; ὁ κατʼ ἀνασκευὴν τρόπος τῆς σ. ib. 31.
remarking, observing of symptoms, Gal. 19.394; used by the νεώτεροι for διάγνωσις acc. to Heliod. ap. Orib. 45.16.4; later, examination, ἡ διὰ τοῦ πυρῆνος σ. Paul.Aeg. 6.77.

children.label: III
children.definition: visible sign or token, as a banner, LXX Ps. 59(60).6.
to be noted as an exception, A.D. Pron. 54.14, etc.
σημειωτέον, one must note, Sor. 2.8, Sch. Ar. Av. 417, etc.
observant of signs, ὁ ὄντως φιλόσοφος σ. Porph. Abst. 2.49. Adv. -κῶς S.E. M. 8.158.

children.label: II
children.definition: -κόν, τό, the science of symptoms in medicine, diagnosis, Gal. 14.689; name of treatise on diagnosis, Sor. 1.124.
signified, inferred from a sign, S.E. P. 2.101, M. 8.166.
of to-day, Call. Sos. vi 2, Ammon. in Int. 32.5, Sch. Ar. Nu. 699, Dosith. p.397 K., Gloss.

to-day, Il. 7.30, Od. 17.186, E. Rh. 683, PHib. 1.65.13 (iii B.C.), SIG 1181.11 ( Rhenea, ii B.C.), Ev.Matt. 27.19, etc.; Dor. σάμερον [ᾱ] Pi. O. 6.28, P. 4.1; Att. τήμερον Cratin. 123, Ar. Eq. 68, etc., cf. Moer. p.364P. (though σήμερον is sts. found in Com., Hermipp. 80, Philem. 121); εἰς τ. Pl. Smp. 174a; τὸ τ. ib. 176e; τὸ τ. εἶναι to-day, Id. Cra. 396e; ἡ τ. ἡμέρα D. 4.40; also in the form τήμερα Ar. Fr. 401 (s.v.l.), cf. 296. (Prob. fr. κy ᾱμερον, containing stem kyo- ‘this’, cf. Lith. šis ‘this’, Lat. ci-tra: σήμερον ( τήμερον) is to ἡμέρα as σῆτες ( τῆτες) to ἔτος.)

definition: σημήϊον, τό, Ion. for σημεῖον. σημιαφόρος, v. σημειοφόρος.

children.definition: semicinctium, apron or kerchief, Act. Ap. 19.12.
holding six modii, Edict.Diocl. 15.51.
placed as a mark, AP 6.295 ( Phan.).

definition: σημοφόριον, τό, dub. rest. in Ἀρχ.Ἐφ. 1913.27 ( Gonni, iii B.C.).

children.definition: Judas-tree, Cercis Siliquastrum, Thphr. HP 3.14.4, 5.7.7.

definition: σημών, ὁ, Lacon. for θημών, EM 711.16.
σηνίκη ἄτροχος ἅμαξα, καὶ τὸ τετράπουν ζῷον, σαύρᾳ παραπλήσιον. καὶ ζῷον πολύπουν, ὅμοιον τοῖς κατοικιδίοις ὄνοις, Hsch. σηνοῦροι· ταῖς οὐραῖς σαίνοντες, Id.

children.definition: causing putrefaction, Heliod. ap. Orib. 47.16.1. Adv. -κῶς ibid.
inclined to putrefy, ἕλκεα Hp. Mul. 1.36, Paul.Aeg. 6.45; ἀήρ Alex.Aphr. Pr. 1.88.
decay, putrefaction, in animal bodies or wood, or even stone, Hp. Epid. 3.4, Antipho Soph. 15, Pl. Phd. 110e, Thphr. CP 6.1.5; σηπεδόνα λαβεῖν Pl. Phd. 96b.
mortification, of two kinds, σ. χλωρή (v. σῆψις) when a humour discharges, and ξηρή when it is dry, Hp. Epid. 5.4.

children.label: II
children.definition: putrid humours, Id. Aph. 3.16 (sg. in 7.20), Plb. 1.81.7, Com.Adesp. 344, etc.

children.label: III
children.definition: a serpent whose bite causes putrefaction, Nic. Th. 327, Ael. NA 15.18.
cause to putrefy, Man. 4.269.

definition: σήπη, ἡ, = σηπεδών, Aq. Jb. 17.14, 21.26, dub. l. in LXX Si. 19.3.

children.definition: cuttle-fish, sepia, Hippon. 68 B, Epich. 61, Ar. Ach. 351, al., Antipho Soph. 78, Arist. HA 524a25, al.; a dainty at Athens, Ar. Ach. 1040, etc.

definition: σηπιάς, άδος, ἡ, = foreg., Nic. Al. 472.
σηπίδιον, τό, Dim. of σηπία, Hp. Mul. 2.133, Ar. Fr. 247, Ephipp. 15.4, Arist. HA 550a16.

children.definition: bone of the sepia or cuttle-fish, pounce, Arist. HA 524b24, 532b1, APo. 98a21 (where σήπειον).
of cuttle-fish and polypus, prob. in Philox. 2.13.
putrefactive, septic, -κὴ κοιλίη digestive stomach, opp. oesophagus, Hp. Anat. 1; τὸ σ. (sc. φάρμακον) Arist. HA 607a22, Thphr. HP 9.16.5; σ. φάρμακον D.S. 4.38: so σηπ-τήριον φ. Hp. Loc.Hom. 38.
converted into excrement, of food, τὸ σ. περίττωμα τοῦ πεφθέντος ἐστίν Arist. GA 762a15; cf. σῆψις II.

data.quote: τὸ σ. περίττωμα τοῦ πεφθέντος ἐστίν

children.label: II
children.definition: Act., = σηπτικός, <δυνάμεις>, i.e. medicines, Dsc. 2.62 (δ. expressed in 3.9); φάρμακον Meges ap. Orib. 44.24.10.

definition: σήπω, A. Ch. 995, Pl. Ti. 84d, etc.: fut. σήψω A. Fr. 275: aor. ἔσηψα ( δι-) Ael. NA 9.62:—

children.definition: make rotten or putrid, A. Fr. l.c.; of a serpentʼs poison, A. Ch. l.c.; of the sting of the σήψ, Ael. NA 16.40.

children.label: b
children.definition: soak hides, δέρματα σ. Supp.Epigr. 3.18 ( Athens, v B.C.).
corrupt, waste, αἱ ἡσυχίαι σήπουσι καὶ ἀπολλύασι Pl. Tht. 153c; σ. τὰ τῆς πόλεως πράγματα D.H. 11.37.

children.label: II
children.definition: Pass. ( pf. σέσηπα being used in pass. sense, Il. 2.135, E. El. 319, ( κατα-) Ar. Pl. 1035, ( ἀπο-) X. An. 4.5.12), fut. σᾰπήσομαι Gal. 7.397, ( κατα-) Pl. Phd. 86b, ( ἀπο-) Hp. Prorrh. 2.1: aor. ἐσάπην [ᾰ] Hes. Sc. 152, Hdt. 2.41, 3.66, Pl. Phd. 80d; σαπήῃ ( κατα-), Ep. subj. for σαπῇ, Il. 19.27: pf. σέσημμαι prob. in POxy. 1449.51 (iii A.D.):— rot, moulder, of dead bodies, χρὼς σήπεται Il. 24.414, cf. 19.27, Hdt. 2.41; περὶ ῥινοῖο σαπείσης Hes. Sc. 152; of wood, δοῦρα σέσηπε Il. 2.135; τριήρης ὑπὸ τερηδόνων σαπεῖσα Ar. Eq. 1308.

mortify, ὁ μηρὸς ἐσάπη Hdt. 3.66; σφακελίσαντος τοῦ μηροῦ καὶ σαπέντος Id. 6.136, cf. Pl. Phd. 80d; αἷμα σέσηπεν E. El. 319; promote coction or formation of ‘laudable’ pus, in Act., Hp. Morb. 1.6, 28.
Id. Aër. 8; οἶνος . . σαπὲν ἐν ξύλῳ ὕδωρ Emp. 81.
Arist. Mete. 381b12, al.; cf. σηπτός, σῆψις II.
σ. ὑπὸ τῆς ἡδονῆς Men. 23; ὁ πλοῦτος ὑμῶν σέσηπε Ep.Jac. 5.2.
sapo, Gloss.; cf. σάπων.

definition: Σήρ, ὁ, gen. Σηρός, mostly in pl. Σῆρες,

children.definition: Seres, the people from whom silk was obtained (i.e. the Chinese), Str. 11.11.1, 15.1.34, D.P. 752, etc.; interpol.(?) in Ctes. Fr. p.86 M. (cod. Monac.):—

children.label: II
children.definition: Adj. Σηρικός (q.v.). silkworm, Paus. 6.26.6.

definition: σήρ, ὁ, Lacon. for θήρ, Hsch.; cf. σηροκτόνος.
σηρά σκῦλα, ἢ δεσμὸς πλεκτός (v. σειρά), Hsch.
σηράγγιον, τό, Dim. of σῆραγξ, a place in the Piraeus, where was a bath, Ar. Fr. 122, Lys. Fr. 17 S., Is. 6.33, Alciphr. 3.43.

children.definition: to be or become hollow, Dsc. 5.121, Hld. 1.28:— Act. σηραγγ-όω, make spongy or porous, τίς ὁ τὸν πνεύμονα -ώσας; Corp.Herm. 5.6.

definition: σήραγγος ἢ σήραγξ· ἐπιθυμία, Hsch.; cf. σηράγγων· σπηλαίων, ἐπιθυμιῶν, Id.

children.definition: full of holes or caverns, Ἴδη Paus. 10.12.4, cf. D.C. 48.51, Agath. 2.15, Lyd. Ost. 53.
porous, spongy, Hp. VC 1, al.; θηλαί Sor. 1.88; νεῦρον Gal. 10.968.

cave hollowed out by water, hollow rock, S. Fr. 549, Pl. Phd. 110a, Arist. HA 548a24, al.; of a lionʼs den, Theoc. 25.223; of the sponge-like pores of the lungs, Pl. Ti. 70c, Ps.-Democr. in Hp. Ep. 23; of the bronchi, Ruf. Onom. 159; medullary cavity of a bone, Antyll. ap. Orib. 44.20.11.

children.label: II
children.definition: used by σηλαγγεύς (q.v.), Agatharch. 27.
silk-worker or silk-mercer, IG 3.3513 (written σιρ-), Edict.Diocl. 20.9, al. (written σειρ-).
silk-weaver, Ps.-Callisth. 3.12.

Seric, silken, ἐσθής Luc. Salt. 63; παραπετάσματα, σκευή, D.C. 43.24, 59.26; νῆμα Gal. 10.942 (pl.), Hld. 2.31; τὰ σ. τῶν ὑφασμάτων Plu. Pyth. 2.396b; written σειρικός, Gal. 5.46:—as Subst., σηρικόν, τό, silken robe, silk, Apoc. 18.12 (v.l. σιρικόν), Peripl.M. Rubr. 49; in pl., Nearch. ap. Str. 15.1.20.
σηρικά, τά, jujubes, Gal. 6.614, Paul.Aeg. 1.81.

σηρικόν (fort. συρικόν), τό, a red pigment, Olymp.Alch. p.76 B., Zos.Alch. p.248 B.; Syricum pigmentum, quod Syrii Phoenices in Rubri maris litoribus colligunt, Isid. Etym. 19.17.6 (where it is distd. from Sericum).

data.quote: Syricum pigmentum, quod Syrii Phoenices in Rubri maris litoribus colligunt,

definition: σηροκτόνος, ον, Lacon. for θηροκτ-, Ar. Lys. 1262.

σής, ὁ, gen. σεός (as if fr. σεύς, which is given as nom. by Choerob. in Theod. 1p.406H.); pl., nom. σέες Moer. p.339P.; gen. σέων Hermipp. 94, Ar. Lys. 730, Ph. 2.461 (not σεῶν, v. Choerob. l.c.); acc. σέας Luc. Ind. 1:—the forms σητός, σῆτες, σητῶν, etc., were later, as in Men. 540.5, Arist. HA 557b3, Thphr. HP 9.11.11, Ph. 2.361 (and v.l. in 2.461), cf. Moer. l.c., etc.:—

children.definition: moth, [ χρυσὸν] οὐ σ. οὐδὲ κὶς δάπτει Pi. Fr. 222, cf. Ar. l.c., Str. 13.1.54, Ev.Matt. 6.19, Ev.Luc. 12.33; attacking books, Luc. l.c.

data.quote: χρυσὸν] οὐ σ. οὐδὲ κὶς δάπτει

children.definition: σῆτες ἀκανθοβάται or -λόγοι, of the Grammarians, bookworms, AP 11.322 ( Antiphan.), 347 ( Phil.).
made of sesame, πλακοῦς Luc. Pisc. 41; μουστάκια σ. ( σησαμᾶτα in codd., perh. rightly) seasoned with sesame, Chrysipp.Tyan. ap. Ath. 14.647d.
sowing (or planting) of sesame, PSI 5.500.3 ( iii B.C., in pl.), PLille 26.1 (iii B.C.).
cultivate sesame, PSI 4.432.3, PTeb. 815 Fr. 3rii 10 (both iii B.C.).
sesame, Sesamum indicum, Gp. 3.2.4.

definition: σησαμῆ, ἡ, contr. from σησαμέα (which occurs in Hdn.Gr. 2.425),

children.definition: a mixture of sesame-seeds, roasted and pounded with honey, an Athenian delicacy, given to guests at a wedding, Ar. Pax 869, Men. 938; in pl., Amphis 9.3; wrongly written σησάμη in Hp. Int. 42, etc.
pertaining to sesame; -κά, τά, accounts relating to sesame, PCair.Zen. 314.4 (iii B.C.).

made of sesame, σ. ἔλαιον sesame-oil, PRev.Laws 40.10 (iii B.C.), PPetr. 3p.218 (iii B.C.), Str. 16.4.26, Dsc. 1.34; δοκοί Peripl.M.Rubr. 36; σ. χρῖμα X. An. 4.4.13 ( σ. ξύλα is prob. f.l. for συκάμινα in Dsc. 1.98).

definition: σησάμιον, τό, Dim. of σησαμῆ, Hdn. Epim. 125.
σησαμίς, Dor. σᾱσᾰμίς, ίδος, ἡ, = σησαμῆ, Stesich. 2, Eup. 163, Antiph. 78.
σησαμίτης [ῑ] (sc. ἄρτος or πλακοῦς), ου, ὁ, bread or a cake

children.definition: made with sesame seeds, Poll. 6.72, Ath. 3.114a: fem. Adj. σησᾰμ-ῖτις, ιδος, planted with sesame, γῆ PSI 5.522.1 (iii B.C.); so ἡ σ. alone, ib. 503.28, 522.11 (iii B.C.); of sesame, sc. κράστις (?), ib. 4.351.16 (iii B.C.).

children.label: II
children.definition: σησαμῖτις, ιδος, ἡ, = σησαμίς II, Ps.- Dsc. 4.149.
like sesame or sesame-seeds, Thphr. HP 3.13.6; of bones, Gal. UP 2.12.

children.label: II
children.definition: σησαμοειδές, τό, fruit of ἐλλέβορος μέλας, Dsc. 4.162; used medicinally, Hp. Acut.(Sp.) 60, Ep. 21; hellebore from Anticyra acc. to Diocl. Fr. 152; also σ. φάρμακον Str. 9.3.3.
σ. τὸ μικρόν, purple rock-cress, Aubrietia deltoidea, Dsc. 4.163 (also called σ. τὸ λευκόν, Ps.- Dsc. ibid.).
σ. τὸ μέγα, bastard rocket, Reseda alba, Dsc. 4.149.
of sesame, ἐδέσματα Hp. Aff. 47; σησαμοῦς ἄρτος Sor. 1.115.

children.label: II
children.definition: Subst. ( contr.) σησαμοῦς (sc. πλακοῦς) sesame-cake, Ar. Ach. 1092, Th. 570.

seed or fruit of the sesame-plant, Hippon. 36 (pl.), Sol. 40 (pl.), Hdt. 1.193, 3.48, 117, Ar. V. 676 (pl.), Thphr. HP 8.1.1, OGI 55.16 ( Telmessus, iii B.C.), PCair.Zen. 787.21 (iii B.C.), etc.: σ. ἄγριον,= κίκι, Ps.- Dsc. 4.161.
τὰ σ. the sesame-market, Moer. p.351P.

children.label: II
children.definition: sesame plant, Ar. Av. 159 (pl.), X. An. 1.2.22, etc.; ἀλείφεσθαι ἐκ τοῦ σ., i.e. with sesame-oil, Str. 16.1.20; cf. σήσαμος.
sprinkled with sesame-seeds, Philox. 3.18.
sesame-seller, IG 2(2).1561.23; fem. σησᾰμό-πωλις, ιδος, ib. 1554.40.
Gp. 9.18.2, Suid.
mess of sesame and cheese, Batr. 36.
compounded of sesame and cheese; or σησᾰμο-ρῡτο-πᾰγής, compounded of sesame and rue, Philox. 3.18.
made of sesame, Sch. Ar. Pax 869.
sesame-bearing, γῆ PMich.Zen. 96.3 (iii B.C.).
toasted with sesame, Philox. 3.16 (corr. Meineke for -φλωκτα).

definition: σησαμώδης, ες, = σησαμοειδής, σπέρμα, καρπός, Thphr. HP 6.5.3, 9.9.2.

one must sift, Dsc. 5.88, Gp. 3.7.1.
sestertius nummus, SIG 674.69 ( Thessaly, ii B.C.); σ. νοῦμμος BGU 326 ii 4 (ii A.D.).

in the style of Sestius: Adv. Comp., Σηστιωδέστερον scriptum, Cic. Att. 7.17.2.

definition: σηστός, ἡ, ( σήθω) nickname of the courtesan Phryne,

children.definition: the sifter, because she drained her lovers of money, Herodic. ap. Ath. 13.591c.

children.label: II
children.definition: σηστὸν καρύων Ποντικῶν, perh. name of a measure, PCair.Zen. 13.22, cf. 12.9 (iii B.C.).

definition: Σηστός, ἡ, Hdt. 7.78, 9.115, and Att. acc. to St.Byz.; also ὁ, X. HG 4.8.5, 6, Ephor. 155 J.:— Sestos, a town on the European side of the Hellespont, over against Abydos, Il. 2.836, etc.:— Adj. Σήστιος, α, ον, IG 1(2).203.10, al.; poet. fem. Σηστιάς, άδος, Musae. 24, 189.
σηστρίδιον, τό, Dim. of sq., PFay. 118.20 (ii A.D.).

children.definition: sieve, Hsch.

definition: σητάνειος [ ᾰ], ον, Plu. Tranq. 2.466d, Favorin. et Orus ap. EM 711.49, 50; σητάνιος, α, ον, Hp. (v. infr.), Dsc. (v. infr.), etc.; Att. τητάνιος

children.definition: Poll. 6.73; Dor. σᾱτάνιος Sch. Ar. Nu. 624:— of this year, σ. πυροί this yearʼs, i.e. spring-wheat, Hp. Acut.(Sp.) 53, Dsc. 2.85 (v.l. σιτ-), cf. 101 (v.l. σιτ-) ἐν πυρῶν κρίμνοις . . σητανίοις Hp. Mul. 1.50 (v.l. σιτ-), Nat.Mul. 57; πυροὶ σιτάνιοι (v.l. σητ-) καὶ ἀλευρῖται, opp. σεμιδαλῖται, Ath.Med. ap. Orib. 1.2.2; σ. κρόμυα Thphr. HP 7.4.7; μῆλα Diph.Siph. ap. Ath. 3.81a; σ. ἄλεμρον Hp. Acut. (Sp.) 63, Dsc. 2.85 (pl.); σ. ἄλητον Hp. Acut. (Sp.) 70, Art. 36; ἄρτος Plu. Tranq. 2.466d (v.l. σιτ-), Anon. in EN 449.10:—cf. σητινός. (Derived by Gal. 18(1).469, Sch. Ar. l.c. from σῆτες = τῆτες, by Suid., Eust. 1792.4, Zonar. from σήθω, as if ‘sifted, boltedʼ; the exact meaning and spelling of σητάν(ε)ιος are uncertain; Plin. has sitanius HN 22.139, setania ib. 19.101; σ. ἄρτος is opp. αὐτόπυρος ἄρτος in Plu. l.c., Anon. in EN l.c.; σατάνειος (q.v.) is prob. not cogn.)

definition: σητάνιον [ ᾰ], τό, = ἐπιμηλίς, Dsc. 1.118; also σιτάνιον Gal. 19.99; cf. σατάνειος.
σητανώδης, ες, = σητάνιος, Hp. ap. Gal. 19.137. (Spelt σιταν-.)

children.definition: fret, of moths, Suid.

definition: σῆτες ( Ion. acc. to EM 711.44), Dor. and Hellenistic σᾶτες IG (v. infr.), PCair.Zen. 346.6 (iii B.C.), EM 711.45:—

eaten by moths, LXX Jb. 13.28, Ep.Jac. 5.2.

definition: σητοδόκιδες ψυχαί, ἢ πτηνὰ ζῷα, Hsch.

putrefying sore, Hp. Epid. 3.7, Dsc. 1.58, al.

children.label: II
children.definition: σήψ, ὁ, Arist., Thphr. (v. infr.), Lucan.9.723:— a serpent, the bite of which causes intense thirst, Arist. Mir. 846b11, Thphr. HP 9.11.1 (cj.), etc.; δίψιος Nic. Th. 147; mortification followed, Ael. NA 16.40.
lizard, Nic. Th. 817; also called σαύρα Χαλκιδική, Dsc. 2.65.
causing mortification by its bite, φαλάγγιον Pl. ap. Arist. Top. 140a4.

definition: σῆψις, Dor. σᾶψις, εως, ἡ, ( σήπομαι)

children.definition: fermentation, putrefaction, decay, αὐχμηραί τε νόσοι καὶ σήψιες Emp. 121; ὑγρῶν σάψιες Ti.Locr. 102c, cf. Arist. HA 569a28; τὸ τέλος τῆς κατὰ φύσιν φθορᾶς σ. ἐστιν Id. Mete. 379a8; σ. χλωρή Hp. Prorrh. 1.99; σ. ὀστέων,= σφάκελος, Moer. p.342P.

data.quote: τὸ τέλος τῆς κατὰ φύσιν φθορᾶς σ. ἐστιν

children.label: II
children.definition: σήπω) the process by which the intestines reject that part of food which is not nutritious, opp. πέψις, Arist. GA 762a14, cf. Ath. 7.276d, and v. σήπω II.4. (Acc. to Gal. 19.373 Empedocles said that πέψις took place σήψει.)

definition: σθεναρός, ά ( Ion. ή), όν, poet. and Ion. Adj.

children.definition: strong, mighty, Ἄτη Il. 9.505; βραχίων E. El. 389; σιδήρια Hp. Fract. 31; intense, καρδιωγμός Id. Mul. 2.126: Comp., ἵππων σθεναρώτερον φυγᾷ πόδα νωμᾶν S. OT 467. Adv. -ρῶς violently, Phld. Sign. 20; ἀπωθεῖν Ph. 1.553.
a trial of strength, an ἀγών at Argos, Plu. Mus. 2.1140c, Hsch.

children.label: II
children.definition: σθένεια, ἡ, the strong one, of Athena, Lyc. 1164; cf. σθένιος.

definition: σθένιος, ὁ, = σθεναρός, epith. of Zeus in the Argolid, Paus. 2.32.7, 2.34.6: fem. σθενιάς, άδος, of Athena, Id. 2.30.6, 2.32.5.

children.definition: hurting the strength, weakening, Opp. C. 2.82.

strength, might, esp. bodily strength, freq. in Il., less freq. in Od.; κάρτεΐ τε σθένεΐ τε Il. 17.329; ἀλκῆς καὶ σθένεος ib. 499; χερσίν τε ποσίν τε καὶ σθένει 20.361; ποδῶν χειρῶν τε σ. Pi. N. 10.48; opp. φρήν, ib. 1.26; γνῶμαι πλέον κρατοῦσιν ἢ σθένος χερῶν S. Fr. 939: c. inf., ἐν δὲ σ. ὦρσεν ἑκάστῳ . . πολεμίζειν strength to war, Il. 2.451; σ. ποιεῖν εὖ φερέγγυον A. Eu. 87; σ. ὥστε καθελεῖν E. Supp. 66 (lyr.): less freq. of the force of things, as of a stream, Il. 17.751; σ. ἀελίου Pi. P. 4.144; [ ἄρουραι] σθένος ἔμαρψαν Id. N. 6.11: σθένει by force, S. OC 842 (lyr.), E. Ba. 953; λόγῳ τε καὶ σθένει both by right and might, S. OC 68; ὑπὸ σθένους E. Ba. 1127; παντὶ σθένει with all oneʼs might, freq. in treaties, SIG 122.6, al., Foed. ap. Th. 5.23, Pl. Lg. 646a—the only phrase in which early prose writers use the word (cf. infr. III); found in LXX, Jb. 4.10, al.

data.quote: χερσίν τε ποσίν τε καὶ σθένει
γνῶμαι πλέον κρατοῦσιν ἢ σθένος χερῶν

children.definition: strength, might, power, moral as well as physical, ἀνάγκης A. Pr. 105; τῆς ἀληθείας S. OT 369; ἀγγέλων σ. their might or authority, A. Ch. 849: c. gen. obj., ἀγωνίας σ. strength for conflict, Pi. P. 5.113 (s.v.l., -ίαις Bgk.); εἰ σ. λάβοιμι if I should gain strength enough, S. El. 333, cf. 348, etc.

children.label: II
children.definition: a force of men, Il. 18.274; ἐπελθὼν οὐκ ἐλάσσονι σ. S. Aj. 438: but in both places sense I.1 is more prob.
quantity, profusion, σ. πλούτου Pi. I. 3.2; ὕδατος, νιφετοῦ, Id. O. 9.51, Fr. 107.11.

children.label: III
children.definition: Idomeneus, Orion, etc. themselves, Il. 13.248, 18.486, Hes. Op. 598, etc.; σ. ἵππων, ἵππιον, Id. Sc. 97, Pi. P. 2.12, etc.:—in Pl. Phdr. 267c, Χαλκηδονίου σ. is ironical.
strengthen, 1 Ep.Pet. 5.10, Hsch. (in fut.).

definition: σθένω, used only in pres. and impf., Trag. Verb, found also in late Ep., and in later Prose, LXX 3 Ma. 3.8, Ael. NA 11.31: ( σθένος):—

children.definition: to have strength or might, be strong or mighty, οὐ γὰρ ἂν σθένοντά γε εἷλέν με in my strength, S. Ph. 947; σθενόντων βραχιόνων E. HF 312: c. dat. modi, σ. χερί, χειρί, ποσίν, to be strong in hand, in foot, S. El. 998, E. Cyc. 651, Alc. 267 (lyr.); also σ. μάχῃ, χρήμασι, Id. Fr. 1048.5, El. 939; σθένοντος ἐν πλούτῳ S. Aj. 488: freq. with a neut. Adj., μέγα, μεῖζον σ., A. Ag. 938, Pr. 1013; οὐδὲν σ. S. OC 846; ὅσον σ. how strong it is, A. Eu. 619; σ. τοσοῦτον S. Aj. 1062; ὅσονπερ ἂν σ. Id. El. 946, cf. Tr. 927; εἰς ὅσον σ. Id. Ph. 1403.
to have power, εἴ τις ἄλλος ἐν πόλει σ. Id. OC 456; πόλις σθένουσα ib. 734; οἱ κάτω σθένοντες they who rule below, the gods below, E. Hec. 49.
σθένουσα λαμπάς A. Ag. 296; ἀστραπαῖσι λαμπάδων σθένει Id. Fr. 386.

inf., to have strength or power to do, be able, mostly with a neg. οὐδέπω μακρὰν πτέσθαι σ. S. OT 17, cf. A.R. 1.62, LXX l.c.; προσβλέπειν γὰρ οὐ σ. S. OT 1486; οὐ γὰρ ἂν σθένοι δέμας ἕρπειν Id. OC 501, cf. 256, 1345, Aj. 165 (anap.), etc.; τὸ σιγᾶν οὐ σ. E. IA 655: with inf. understood, τόδʼ, εἴπερ ἔσθενον, ἔδρων ἄν S. El. 604; εἶμι . . ὅποιπερ ἂν σ. Id. Aj. 810, etc.

data.quote: οὐ γὰρ ἂν σθένοι δέμας ἕρπειν

σιαγόνιον, Ion. σῐηγ-, τό, in pl.,

jaw-bone, jaw, Hp. Epid. 3.17.βʹ, S. Fr. 112, Ar. Fr. 287, PCair.Zen. 76.12 (iii B.C.), LXX Jd. 15.14, al.; of an ox, Cratin. 163; of a camel, prob. in PLond. 3.909 ( a). 7 (ii A.D.); κινεῖται δὲ τοῖς . . ζῴοις ἅπασιν ἡ κάτωθεν σ., κτλ., Arist. HA 516a24, cf. 492b22; cheek, Cerc. 5.6, Ev.Matt. 5.39:—written συαγών, BGU 100.5 (ii A.D.), cf. Ath. 3.94f; also σεαγών, BGU 153.17, 35 (ii A.D.), Sammelb. 5167.11.

Call. Fr. 100c6.
slaver, foam, Archig. ap. Gal. 13.170 ( σιελ-) ἦχοι . . σιελίζοντες noises in the throat with expectoration, Hp. Prorrh. 1.114, cf. Hsch.
bird, Did. ap. Ath. 9.392f.

flow of saliva, Gal. 7.470 ( -ελ-), 16.146 ( -αλ-), Ruf. ap. Orib. 8.24.64 ( -ελ-), Archig.ib. 8.2.6 ( -ελ-).
bridle-bit, which is apt to be covered with foam, Gp. 16.1.11 (where -ελ-).
spittle, saliva, Hp. Aph. 7.16, Pherecr. 69, X. Mem. 1.2.54; σιάλῳ παιδία παραλείφειν Democrates ap. Arist. Rh. 1407a8.

children.definition: synovial fluid, Hp. Carn. 10. [ Att. σίαλον, τό, Hellenic σίελος, ὁ, acc. to Moer. p.347P.; the latter occurs LXX Is. 40.15 (neut. σίελον cod.A), Aret. SD 2.2, PMag.Par. 1.132: pl. τὰ σίελα LXX 1 Ki. 21.13.]

definition: σιαλοπάλλαγος ὁ παράληρος, καὶ ἀνόητος, Hsch.

fat hog, Il. 21.363, Od. 2.300, 20.163, Q.S. 11.170; also σῦς σ. Il. 9.208, Od. 14.41, 81, etc., where σίαλος is the specific Subst., added as in ἴρηξ κίρκος, σῦς κάπρος, etc.:—also in Prose, Thphr. ap. Porph. Abst. 2.25.
fat, grease, Hp. Acut. (Sp.) 37 codd. MV, but λάσιον is prob. to be restored fr. Erot. and Gal.
letting the spittle run, Aret. SA 1.7, SD 2.6; σ. ἀδένες the salivary glands, Gal. 16.508: hence σῐᾰ
secrete saliva, Hp. Vict. 2.47; slaver, Id. Morb. 3.10.
fatten, in Pass. σιαλοῦται, Hsch.:— Act. σιαλῶσαι· ποικῖλαι, Id.
like slaver, slavering, Hp. Morb. Sacr. 5, D.P. 791.

children.definition: σίαλος) fat, σκυλάκια Hp. Steril. 217.
ornamental shield-rim, Plb. 6.23.4; cf. σιγάλωμα.
nuisance, ἀπαλλαγῆναι τῆς σ. ταύτης POxy. 1855.13 (vi/vii A.D.); = fastidium, Gloss.
taeter, Gloss.; cf. sq. [σιαντόφρικτος]
horridus, Gloss. (fort. σιαντός· φρικτός).

senses.definition: σιβδία· σιδία, Hsch. σίβληθρα· πόπανα τὰ περικεκνισμένα, Id.

Pr. 954a36, is no exception), first localized at Erythrae or Cumae, Id. Mir. 838a6; later, others are mentioned, cf. Str. 14.1.34, Paus. 10.12.1 sqq., Sch. Pl. l.c., Buresch Klaros p.120. [ Σίβιλλα IG 2(2).1534.85 (iv B.C.).]
foretell like a Sibyl, D.S. 4.66.

definition: Σιβύλλειος, ον, Sibylline, Σ. βίβλοι, at Rome, Plu. Fab. 4; τὰ Σ. D.H. 6.17, Plu. Marc. 3, etc.; also Σιβυλλ-ιακός, ή, όν, D.S. 34/ 5.10.

children.definition: want the Sibyl, = χρησμῶν ἐρᾶν (Sch. l.c.), Ar. Eq. 61.
believer in the Sibyl, Cels. ap. Origenes Cels. 5.61; seer, diviner, Plu. Mar. 42.

definition: σιβύνη [ ῠ], ἡ, and σῐβύνης [ ῠ], ου, ὁ, Alex. 131 (fem.), AP 7.421 ( Mel.), 6.93 (Antip., masc.):—

children.definition: hunting spear, and generally, spear, pike, D.S. 18.27, 20.33:—also written ζιβύνη (q.v.), συβίνη, PCair.Zen. 362.34 (iii B.C.), cf. συ[μ]βίνη[ς] (post συβήνη) · καπροβόλον, ἐμβόλιον, Hsch., but σιγύνης [ῡ] is prob. not related. (Illyrian acc. to Fest. p.453 L., citing Ennius.)

definition: σιβύνιον [ ῠ], τό, Dim. of foreg., Plb. 6.23.9.

children.definition: silently, used in Trag. (and late Ep., A.R. 1.267), σῖγʼ ἔχοντες S. Ph. 258; σῖγʼ ἔχουσα πρόσμενε Id. El. 1236; ἀλλὰ σ. πρόσμενε ib. 1399; ἄκουε σ. Id. Fr. 815; κάθησο σ. Ar. Ach. 59: also as an exclam., σῖγα hush! be still! A. Ag. 1344; so οὐ σ.; Id. Th. 250; οὐ σῖγʼ ἀνέξει; S. Aj. 75; the public crier proclaiming silence said σ. πᾶς (sc. ἔστω), Ar. Ach. 238, cf. E. Hec. 532; σ. κηρῦξαι στρατῷ Id. Ph. 1224.

under oneʼs breath, in a whisper, quietly, secretly (cf. σιγή II), τὰ δὲ σ. τις βαΰζει A. Ag. 449; σῖγʼ ἐπέρχεται φάτις S. Ant. 700; σ. σήμαινε Id. Ph. 22; σ. μὲν ἡρώεσσιν ἐκέκλετο Orph. A. 702; πῶς αἱ πατρῷαί σʼ ἄλοκες φέρειν . . σῖγʼ ἐδυνάθησαν; S. OT 1212.

definition: σίγα, imper. of σιγάω (q. v.):— σιγά, Dor. for σιγή.
σιγᾷ, 3 sg. of σιγάω; or Dor. dat. of σιγή.

children.definition: bid one be silent, silence him, Ζεφύρου πνοάς Pi. Parth. 2.16; τινα(ς) X. An. 6.1.32, D.C. 64.14; τύμπανα Opp. C. 3.286:— Pass., D.C. 39.34.
silent, still, AP 7.597 ( Jul.), Orph. A. 1003, etc.
glossy, glittering, Ep. Adj.:
σ. χιτών Od. 15.60, 19.232; εἵματα Il. 22.154, Od. 6.26; ῥήγεα ib. 38; δέσματα Il. 22.468; cf. νεοσίγαλος.

glittering with colour or metal work, Od. 6.81, Il. 5.226, etc.; of house-furniture, θρόνος Od. 5.86; of a queenʼs chamber, ὑπερώϊα σιγαλόεντα 16.449, 18.206, etc.; νηὸν [σιγ]αλόεντα IG 14.1026 (iii/iv A.D.).

children.definition: fatty, oily, ἀμύγδαλα Hermipp. 63.20; μνία Numen. ap. Ath. 7.295c.
make smooth, polish, Apollon. Lex. s.v. σιγαλόεντα.
instrument for smoothing or polishing, esp. of shoemakers for smoothing leather, Apollon. Lex. s.v. σιγαλόεντα, Hsch. s.v. σιγαλόεντα.

children.label: II
children.definition: border, edging of a dress, Id.; v. σιάλωμα.

definition: σιγᾶς, i.e. perh. Dor. contr. from *σιγάεις (

children.definition: silent, dub. in A. Ag. 412 (lyr.).

definition: σιγάω, Dor. 2 sg. σιγῇς Ar. Ach. 778; Cyrenaic inf. σιγέν Berl.Sitzb. 1927.170; 1 sg. opt. σιγῷμ ( ι) E. Hipp. 336: fut. -ήσομαι S. OC 113, 980, E. Ba. 801, Ar. Av. 1684, etc.; later -ήσω AP 9.27 ( Arch. or Parmen.), D.Chr. 37.42, Charito 1.10: pf. σεσίγηκα Aeschin. 3.218:— Pass., fut. σιγηθήσομαι E. IT 1076; σεσιγήσομαι Pl. Ep. 311c: aor. ἐσιγήθην E. Supp. 298, Aeschin. 2.86: pf. σεσίγημαι (v. infr.): ( σιγή):—

children.definition: keep silence, used by Hom. only in imper. σίγα, hush! be still! Il. 14.90, Od. 17.393; σιγᾶν h.Merc. 93, Hdt. 8.61, 110; but freq. in Pi., Trag., and Att., as Pi. N. 10.29, A. Pr. 200, etc.; σ. περί τινος E. Hipp. 312; πρὸς οὓς δεῖ Pl. Phdr. 276a; πρὸς τοῦτο, ἐν τούτῳ, X. Cyr. 5.5.20, An. 5.6.27.

σιγῶν δʼ ὄλεθρος καὶ μέγα φωνοῦντʼ . . ἀμαθύνει A. Eu. 935 (anap.); σύριγγες οὐ σιγῶσιν Id. Supp. 181; σίγησε δʼ αἰθήρ E. Ba. 1084; σ. πόντος, σ. ἀῆται, ἁ δʼ ἐμὰ οὐ σ. ἀνία Theoc. 2.38:—in E. Fr. 781.13, τὰ σιγῶντʼ ὀνόματʼ . . δαιμόνων seems to be = τὰ ἄρρητα, secret, mystical:— Pass., μέμψομαι σιωπὴν ὡς ἐσιλγήθη κακῶς I shall impute as a fault that silence was kept, Id. Supp. 298; also τί σεσίγηται δόμος Ἀδμήτου; why is it all silent? Id. Alc. 78; σιγῶντα λέγειν, λέγοντα σιγᾶν, phrases illustrating a logical fallacy, Pl. Euthd. 300b, Arist. SE 166a13.

data.quote: σιγῶν δʼ ὄλεθρος καὶ μέγα φωνοῦντʼ . . ἀμαθύνει
σ. πόντος, σ. ἀῆται, ἁ δʼ ἐμὰ οὐ σ. ἀνία

children.label: II
children.definition: hold silent, keep secret, Pi. Fr. 81, A. Pr. 106, 441, Ag. 36, Hdt. 7.104 (s. v. l.), etc.:— Pass., to be kept silent or secret, σεσιγαμένον χρῆμα Pi. O. 9.103; ὁ θάνατος . . ἐσιγήθη Hdt. 5.21; σιγώμενος S. Fr. 653; ἐσιγάθη δʼ ἂν ὑφορβός would never have been heard of, Theoc. 16.54.

singularis; εἴλη Σιν[γ]λαρίων,= ala Singularium, IGRom. 4.1213 ( Thyatira, iii A.D.); σιγγουλάριος, Lyd. Mag. 3.7, PLond. 5.1797.6 (vi A.D.), etc.; written σινγουλάρις or σῑγᾰλ-ιος, Baillet Inscriptions des tombeaux des rois à Thèbes 1473, 1688.

children.label: II
children.definition: ἱππεὺς σινγλάρις,= eques singularis, IGRom. 3.394 (= 503) ( Pisidia, iii A.D.).

definition: σιγγρίασις, εως, ἡ, = ἄφθα (A), in horses, Hippiatr. 97 ( v.l. σιγρίασις).

children.definition: Lacon. for θιγεῖν, Ar. Lys. 1004, cf. Hsch. s.v. σίγε.
one that steals silently to a place, Call. Epigr. 45.6 (cj. Bentl., for σειγάρνης cod. Pal., cf. σιγέρπης· λαθροδάκτης, Hsch.).

silence, σ. ἔχειν keep silence, Hdt. 1.86; σ. ποιήσασθαι make silence, Id. 6.130; παρέχειν S. Tr. 1115, etc.; σ. φυλάσσετε E. IA 542; σ. τῶνδε θήσομαι πέρι Id. Med. 66; γύναι, γυναιξὶ κόσμον ἡ σ. φέρει S. Aj. 293; κόσμος ἡ σ. τε καὶ τὰ παῦρʼ ἔπη Id. Fr. 64; ὦ παῖ, σιώπα· πόλλʼ ἔχει σ. καλά Id. Fr. 81; πολλῶν φάρμακον κακῶν σ. Carc. 7.2; δυσμενὴς τῇ σ. Hdt. 7.237; ἡ ἄγαν σ. S. Ant. 1251, cf. 1256: pl., σιγαὶ ἀνέμων E. IA 10 (anap.); σιγαὶ . . τῶν νεωτέρων παρὰ πρεσβυτέροις Pl. R. 425b.

data.quote: γύναι, γυναιξὶ κόσμον ἡ σ. φέρει
κόσμος ἡ σ. τε καὶ τὰ παῦρʼ ἔπη
ὦ παῖ, σιώπα· πόλλʼ ἔχει σ. καλά

children.label: b
children.definition: Aristeas 95, Apoc. 8.1; σ. σύμβολον θεοῦ ζῶντος PMag.Par. 1.559.

children.label: II
children.definition: σιγῇ, as Adv., in silence, the only case used by Hom., πάντες ἥατο σιγῇ Il. 19.255, cf. 3.8, al.; also διὰ σιγῆς, μετὰ σ., Pl. Grg. 450c, Sph. 264a; σὺν σιγῇ Critias 25.22: like σῖγα, as an exclam., σιγῇ νῦν be silent now! Od. 15.440.

in an undertone, in a whisper, secretly (cf. σῖγα 2), σ. λόγον ἐποιέετο Hdt. 8.74; τὰ σ. βουλευόμενα X. Mem. 1.1.19; σιγῇ ἔχειν τι keep it secret, Hdt. 9.93; σιγᾷ καλύψαι, σιγῇ στέγειν, κεύθειν, Pi. N. 9.7, S. OT 341, Tr. 989 (anap.).
σιγῇ τινος unknown to him, Hdt. 2.140, E. Med. 587.

definition: σιγηλός, ή, όν, Dor. σῑγᾱλός, όν, Pi. P. 9.92:—

children.definition: silent, Hp. Acut. 65, S. Ph. 741, Nicopho 27; disposed to silence, S. Tr. 416; of animals, Arist. HA 488a34; τὰ ἐκ ποδῶν σιγηλὰ σῴζοντες E. Ba. 1049. Adv. -λῶς Poll. 5.147.
Att. form for σιγηλός, Men. Mon. 167, Hp. Ep. 12; opp. talkative, γυνή LXX Si. 26.14. Adv. -ρῶς Hsch.
one must be silent, E. Hel. 1387.
one who keeps silence, of Bacchic initiates, in pl., AJA 37.262 ( Latium, ii A.D., σειγ-).

definition: σιγητικός, ή, όν, = σιγηλός, Hp. Decent. 3.

children.definition: sigillaria, puppets, M.Ant. 7.3.

definition: σίγιον, τό, a kind of cicada, Sch. Ar. Av. 1095.

children.definition: cupboard door, POxy. 1923.5 (v/vi A.D.).
ear-ring, PMasp. 340v77 (vi A.D.), Hsch.; Aeol. acc. to Poll. 5.97.

definition: σίγλος or σίκλος (the latter form in LXX, J., and S. (v. infr.)), ὁ,

children.definition: shekel, a weight ( LXX Ex. 30.23, al.) or coin (ib. Le. 5.15); δραχμὴ μία τὸ ἥμισυ τοῦ σ. ib. Ex. 39.2 ( 38.26); but ὁ σ. … Ἀττικὰς δέχεται δραχμὰς τέτταρας J. AJ 3.8.2, cf. Hsch. s.v. σίκλος.

data.quote: ὁ σ. … Ἀττικὰς δέχεται δραχμὰς τέτταρας

children.definition: = 7 1/2 Att. ὀβολοί, X. An. 1.5.6; or 8 ὀβολοί, acc. to Phot., quoting S. Fr. 1094 (perh. erroneously, instead of for sense II).

children.label: II
children.definition: ear-ring, Phot., cf. sq. [σιγλοφόρος]

children.label: III
children.definition: Plb. 34.8.7, prob. corrupt for Σικελικός.
wearing ear-rings, Com.Adesp. 792.
sigma, v. Σς.

children.label: II
children.definition: a Ϲ shaped portico, Princeton Exp.Inscr. III A No. 560 (v A.D.), JHS 28.195 (Aspendus, written σῖμμα).
sigma, crescent-shaped dining-table, Mart. 10.48.6, etc.
write with sigma, διπλῶς σιγματίζεται is written with double σ, Eust. 1389.15.

definition: σιγματοειδής, ές, = σιγμοειδής, Onos. 21.6, Zos. 3.11.3; ἐκκοπή Apollon. Cit. ap. Erot. s.v. ἄμβην (v.l. σιγμο-). Adv. -δῶς Sch. Il. 9.5.

children.definition: of the shape of sigma (Ϲ), crescent-shaped, semicircular, ἀπόφυσις Gal. UP 13.12; of the moon, Cleom. 2.5. Adv. σιγμοειδῶς Heliod. ap. Orib. 49.8.6.
hissing, as of tortoises, Arist. HA 536a7; as a signal, Plu. Gen.Socr. 2.593b; in Magic, Plot. 2.9.14; in Gramm., of sibilants, D.T. 631.18, Phld. Po.Herc. 994.33, S.E. M. 1.102.
statue, IG 14.971 ( Rome, iii A.D.).

children.label: II
children.definition: the place where the standards were set up in a camp, used as a store, prison, etc., PLond. 2.413.12 (iv A.D.), PLond. ined. 2487.18 (iv A.D.).
signifer, of begging priests ( μηναγύρται), Tz. H. 13.245.
wild swine, βραχεῖς καὶ σιμοί, Hsch.

spear, Hdt. 5.9, Opp. C. 1.152; also σίγῡνος, ὁ, A.R. 2.99, AP 6.176 codd. ( Maced.); σίγῡνον, τό, Arist. Po. 1457b6, AP 7.578 ( Agath.); and in Lyc. 556, σίγυμνον (in dat. -ῳ).—Cyprian acc. to Hdt. and Arist. ll. cc., Scythian acc. to Sch.Par. A.R. 4.320 (cf. III).

children.label: II
children.definition: σιγύνης among the Ligyes near Marseilles was used for κάπηλος, Hdt. l.c.

children.label: III
children.definition: Σιγύνναι, οἱ, a people on the Middle Danube, Hdt. l.c.; in A.R. 4.320, Σίγυννοι; in Str. 11.11.8, Σίγιννοι. [In A.R. and Opp., ῡ; freq. written with double ν, σιγύννης, etc.]

definition: σίδαρος, Dor. for σίδηρος; for all forms in σιδαρ-, v. σιδηρ-.

children.definition: of the pomegranate, Hdn.Gr. 1.135.
a boy in his fifteenth or sixteenth year, Phot. s.v. συνέφηβος.
pomegranate tree and fruit, Emp. 80, Hp. Nat.Mul. 32, Ulc. 11: Boeot. σίδα for Att. ῥόα, Epaminond. ap. Agatharch. Fr. Hist. 8 J.; σιδέα, IG 14.352 i 54 (Halaesa, pl.); σίβδα, Call. Lav.Pall. 28.

children.label: II
children.definition: Thphr. HP 4.10.1, Nic. Th. 887. [ ῑ in signf. I, ib. 72, 870, etc.; but ῐ in signf. I, Emp. l.c., and in signf. II, Nic. Th. 887; cf. σίδιον, σιδόεις.]
attracting iron, of the magnet, S.E. M. 1.226.
working in iron, X. An. 5.5.1.
iron-mines, Arist. Pol. 1259a25, Thphr. HP 5.9.2, Lap. 52, Str. 1.2.39: sg. -εῖον, τό, IG ΙΙ(2).161 A 19 ( Delos, iii B.C.).
iron-banded, Edict.Diocl. 15.50 (Megalop.).
βρόχοι Epic.Alex.Adesp. 9 ix 12.

definition: σιδήρεος, α, Ion. and Ep. η, ον, Att. contr. σιδηροῦς, ᾶ, οῦν SIG 144.14, etc.; Ep. also σιδήρειος, η, ον, v. infr.; also late, Stud.Pal. 20.217.9 (vi A.D.) (fem. -ειος Theognost. Can. 56); Dor. σιδάρεος [ᾱ] IG 42(1).103.114 ( Epid., iv B.C.), and v. infr. II, also σιδάριος SIG 246 ii 67 ( Delph., iv B.C.); Aeol. σιδάριος Theoc. 29.24:—

children.definition: made of iron or steel, ἄξων Il. 5.723; σιδηρείη κορύνη 7.141; πύλαι 8.15; ὑποκρητηρίδιον Hdt. 1.25; σκύταλον Theoc. 17.31; χεὶρ σ. grappling-iron, Th. 4.25, 7.62: also σ. ὀρυμαγδός, i.e. the clang of arms, Il. 17.424; σ. οὐρανός the iron sky, the firmament, which the ancients held to be of metal, Od. 15.329 (cf. χάλκεος) ; σ. γένος, of the Iron age, Hes. Op. 176.

ἦ γὰρ σοί γε σ. ἐν φρεσὶ θυμός a soul of iron, i.e. hard, stubborn as iron, Il. 22.357, cf. Od. 23.172; οὐδέ μοι . . θυμὸς ἐνὶ στήθεσσι σ., ἀλλʼ ἐλεήμων 5.191; οὐδʼ εἴ οἱ κραδίη γε σ. ἔνδοθεν ἦεν 4.293; σιδήρειόν νύ τοι ἦτορ Il. 24.205, 521; ἦ ῥά νυ σοί γε σ. πάντα τέτυκται thou art iron all! Od. 12.280; πυρὸς μένος . . σ. the iron force of fire, Il. 23.177; of Heracles, the iron-sided, Simon. 8; of men, Ar. Ach. 491; σὰρξ σ. Theoc. 22.47; ὦ σιδήρεοι O ye ironhearted! Aeschin. 3.166; εἰ μὴ σιδηροῦς ἐστιν, οἴομαι ἔννουν γεγονέναι Lys. 10.20; σ. λόγοι Pl. Grg. 509a.

data.quote: οὐδέ μοι . . θυμὸς ἐνὶ στήθεσσι σ., ἀλλʼ ἐλεήμων
οὐδʼ εἴ οἱ κραδίη γε σ. ἔνδοθεν ἦεν
εἰ μὴ σιδηροῦς ἐστιν, οἴομαι ἔννουν γεγονέναι

children.label: II
children.definition: σιδάρεοι, οἱ, Byzantine iron coins, always used in Dor. form, even at Athens, Ar. Nu. 249, Pl.Com. 96, Stratt. 36.
worker in iron, smith, X. Ages. 1.26, Vect. 4.6, Aret. SD 1.11, Them. Or. 20.236 d.
work in iron, Poll. 7.105.

definition: σιδηρήεις, εσσα, εν, poet. for σιδήρεος, Nic. Al. 51, Man. 1.313.

children.definition: to be like iron, of the magnet, Gal. 11.612; of chalybeate baths, etc., Antyll. ap. Orib. 10.3.1, Paul.Aeg. 1.52, 6.21.

definition: σιδήριον ( Dor. σιδάριον Schwyzer 180.5 ( Crete)), τό,

children.definition: implement or tool of iron, IG 1(2).313.128 (v B.C.); θερμοῖσι σ. ἐκκαίειν τοὺς ὀφθαλμούς with hot irons, Hdt. 7.18; ἐπαΐοντες σιδηρίων feeling iron, not being proof against it, Id. 3.29; of a knife, Id. 9.37, cf. Lys. 1.42; σ. εἰς κρεονομίαν PCair.Zen. 720.3 (iii B.C.); σ. λιθουργά, of a stonemasonʼs tools, Th. 4.4, cf. Thphr. Lap. 41; σιδηρίων μισθός IG 2(2).1656; λίθους καὶ ξύλα καὶ σ. Pl. Euthd. 300b; σ. πλατέα Arist. Cael. 313a17.

children.label: II
children.definition: iron, Daimachus 4J. (v.l. σίδηρον).
faber ferrarius, Gloss.
spatula, Supp. Epigr. 1.414 ( Crete, v/iv B.C.).

definition: σιδηρίτης [ ῑτ], ου, ὁ, fem. σῐδηρ-ῖτις, ιδος: Dor. σῐδᾱρίτας, α, ὁ:—

children.definition: of iron, σ. πόλεμος iron war, Pi. N. 5.19; σ. τέχνη the smithʼs art, Eup. 263; σ. πέτρα rock with iron ore in it, D.S. 5.13; σ. γῆ Arist. Fr. 326 ed. Berol., Poll. 3.87.
σιδηρῖτις, with or without λίθος, loadstone, Phld. Sign. 9, Str. 15.1.38, Plu. QPlat. 2.1005c, etc.
a precious stone, Plin. HN 37.58, al.; used as remedy for snake-bite, Orph. L. 361, 390, 419.

children.label: II
children.definition: σιδηρῖτις, ἡ, ironwort, Sideritis romana, Dsc. 4.33, Plin. HN 25.43, Aret. CD 2.12; also σ. πόα Hsch.; βοτάνη ἡ σ. J. AJ 3.7.6, Gal. 12.885.
Dsc. to burnet, Poterium Sanguisorba, 4.34; Cretan fig-wort, Scrophularia lucida, ib. 35; Achilles’ woundwort, Achillea tomentosa, ib. 36.
provision, supply of iron, PMasp. 57.12 (vi A.D.), PFlor. 297.41 (vi A.D.).
of ferruginous colour, Lyd. Mens. 4.30.
anchor, Sch. Luc. Lex. 15.
a file, Opp. C. 2.174.
iron-loaded, ξύλον E. Fr. 531.
iron-eating, θηγάνη S. Aj. 820; where the Sch. has a fem. form σῐδηρο-βρῶτις, ιδος.
iron-fingered, κρεάγρη AP 6.101 ( Phil.).
with bonds of iron, ἀνάγκαι LXX 3 Ma. 4.9.
bind in iron, Heraclit. Ep. 7.8 ( Pass.).
iron-bound, πόρπακες B. Fr. 3; ἐδέδετο ἐν ξύλῳ σ., of stocks, Hdt. 9.37; μόχλοι J. BJ 6.5.3.
armoury, Hsch. s.v. ὀγκίαι.
with iron breastplate, Sch.D Il. 2.47, 3.131.
condemned to the iron, i.e. mutilated, Suid. s.v. σπάδων.
slain by iron, i.e. by the sword, used with neut. dat. βοτοῖς, S. Aj. 325; cf. ἀνδροκμής.
iron-sheathed, μάχαιρα PCair.Zen. 54.41 (iii B.C.).

definition: σιδηροκόντρα, ἡ, in pl., perh. gladiatorial contest

children.definition: with barbed iron spears, Ausonia 6.9* ( Gortyn); sg. in IGRom. 3.360 ( Sagalassus); cf. κοντροκυνηγέσιον.
faber ferrarius, Gloss.
armed with iron, Ἕλλαν Tim. Pers. 155.
mother of iron, αἶα A. Pr. 303.
distributing with iron, i.e. with the sword, χείρ A. Th. 788 (lyr.).
iron-backed, ἀσπίδος τύποι E. Ph. 1130.
iron fetter, Eust. 1411.32.
moulded of iron, Luc. Ocyp. 164.
smitten by iron, A. Th. 911 (lyr.).
